description:
1.	Site Reconnaissance – which has already begun. We know the neighborhood. We have already restored compartment numbers 67, 66, 65, and 64. Compartments numbers 69, 74, and 75 are congruent. The reconnaissance has involved taking note of the climate (temperature and rainfall distribution), soil, topography, waterflows, vegetation characteristics, and the sociology of the communities. These have guided the choice of tree species selection for the project.

2.	Community Engagement: Sakam Savana in collaboration with the community leaders and the partners — the traditional leaders, district, regional, and national agencies of the government— will engage the community in early January 2024, just before the project starts, to introduce the restoration initiative.  The core objective of the engagement is to foster deeper understanding and cooperation between Sakam Savana and the host communities. Sakam Savana will reiterate the desire to co-live for and co-govern and co-share and co-benefit from the project. Sakam Savana will invite the community to design together schemes of governance for various communal-benefit intervention schemes that engender good spirit for the community and the forest restoration.  

3.	Nursery: Nursery comes a bit early. Seed collection starts in anticipation of the future. Seeds collection and nursery preparations may have to start once announcement is made.  The active nursery commences mid January.

4.	Preparation of the planting site: Site preparation will start in January 2024 to usher the community members’ labour to enable them gain income. Site preparation means removing competing vegetation from the site and creating conditions that will enable the soil to catch and absorb as much rainfall as possible. Site preparation includes an application of organic manure. Manure application assists the seedlings for rapid growth and supports the farmers who will be offered land to get better yield.

5.	Fire belt: Fire-ride will be constructed in 14 days from March 1, 2024 – March 14, 2024

6.	Planting of seedlings processes. Planting starts around mid May 2024, when the rains start, for six weeks ending on June15, 2024.
7.	Plantation Management and maintenance:
i.	First weeding and tendering commences Sep.1, 2024 – Sep. 30, 2024
ii.	Second weeding and tendering commences on Nov. 1, 2024 – Nov. 30, 2024
iii.	Community engagement: About Dec. 17, the official of Sakam Savana will call for community engagement. An expert of sustainability and economic resilient will be invited to broach conversation regarding planting fruit-bearing trees to adapt to alternative livelihoods.
iv.	Fire-watch begins in and around Dec. 20, 2024 – Mar. 15, 2025.  

8.	Periodic M&E and Reporting: In every March, June, September, and December, of 2024 to 2029, and extensive monitoring and evaluation activities will be conducted.  In January and July, a report that explains progress and challenges and solutions/way forward (mitigation and adaptation for the project’s success) will be sent to TerraMatch.

9.	First weed control:
i.	First weeding and tendering commences March.15, 2025 – Apr. 30, 2024
ii.	Second weeding and tendering commences on Jul. 1, 2025 – Aug. 30, 2025

10.	Beating up: Budgeted for 20% mortality of the first planting. From Jul 15, 2025 – Aug 31, 2025

11.	Fire Prevention Plan: Preparing towards fire-watch and prevention (with the communities) towards ensuing drought beginning December 20, 2025, and enters through to March 15, 2026.

12.	Weed control:
i.	First weeding and tendering commences March.15, 2026 – Apr. 30, 2026
ii.	Intensive Pruning maybe required. Pruning starts on Jul. 15, 2026 – Aug. 31, 2026
iii.	Second weeding and tendering commences on Jul. 1, 2026 – Aug. 30, 2026

13.	Pruning and thinning and tendering: The years 2027, 2028, and 2029 are for tree management particularly. We will prune and thin mostly. We will pay practical attention to regeneration.
14.	Fire Prevention activities will continue during every Harmattan beyond the TerraFund Project closure date.
 
15.	Alternative Livelihood Interventions: These are intensified from 2027. Though Sakam Savana focuses on bringing “horticulture”, which is incorporated in the fire prevention scheme, alternative schemes such as bee keeping and animal rearing under the trees, would consist as a distinct approach to involve the community’s participation in forestry conservation to mitigate climate catastrophe and fostering effective adaptation.

project_name: Agriculture and forest landscape restoration - Goshen Global Vision
description:
January through February 2022 – Stakeholder engagements, procurement of seeds from Government Agency (Forestry Research Institute of Ghana (FORIG)). At the same time, sites for establishing seedling nursery will be identified by community members and other stakeholders, site preparation activities will commence with women and the youth, including preparation of germination beds, filling of polyethylene pots with compost soil and procurement of nursery tools.
March 2022 – Various seeds procured will go through treatment to break dormancy, which will range from soaking seeds in lukewarm, warm and boiling water depending on the characteristic of a particular seed and placed on germination beds, provided with shade/mulch and watered regularly. 
April through May – Community members will transfer seedlings from germination beds and transplanted into polyethylene pots at the nursery and regularly watered and maintained to minimize disease and pest attacks. June, July, August, 2022 –. Trainings on outplanting of seedlings to minimize shock and good planting methods will be conducted in all the various communities. This period falls within the major raining season. 100,000 seedlings will be out-planted in the field. 
 September, November, 2022 – Seedling monitoring with farmers, volunteers and stakeholders (Forestry Commission and Ghana Cocoa Board) coupled with education on management practices to ensure good survival rate.
 December 2022 – collection of monitoring data
January-December 2023 – The cycle described above will be repeated for another 100,000 during this period.

project_name: AVOCADO TREE FRUITS, SEEDLINGS REDISTRIBUTION AND  AGRI BUSINESS CONSULTANCY PROJECT
description:
Our project's main activities are divided into several key stages, each with its own timeline and expected outcomes. Here's a breakdown:

Soil Preparation and Seed Planting (1st March to 1st April 2024):
During this period, our team will focus on soil preparation, which involves tasks such as soil sieving to remove debris and ensure optimal soil texture for plant growth.
Additionally, we'll be potting the soil into avocado seeds and planting them in suitable containers or directly in the prepared soil.
The goal here is to initiate the germination process and provide the young seedlings with the necessary environment to establish their root systems.

Grafting and Gestation Period (After 1st April 2024):
Following the initial planting phase, our attention will shift towards grafting the seedlings. Grafting is a horticultural technique where tissues from one plant are inserted into those of another so that they will unite and grow as one plant.
After grafting, we'll enter a gestation period where the grafted seedlings will need time to develop and strengthen. This period typically spans around three months, during which we'll monitor the progress of the plants closely.

Plantation Preparation (From November 2024):
As we approach November 2024, assuming the gestation period proceeds as expected, our focus will shift to preparing the seedlings for plantation.
This preparation includes ensuring that the seedlings are adequately hardened off and ready for transplantation into the field.
However, the timing of plantation will largely depend on the confirmation of sufficient rainfall. Avocado trees require a consistent water supply, particularly during their early stages of growth. Therefore, we'll wait for rain confirmation to ensure the optimal conditions for successful transplantation.

From January 2025- Mass mobilization of farmers and planting of avocado seedlings, for the first 6 months all plantation will be done. From June to December 2025, we are monitoring the seedlings survival rate and replacing the dead seedlings.
From Jan 2025-2029- Seedlings monitoring , husbandry and tree feeding programs adopted. After 3 year in planting- Harvesting of the first fruits and linking to export market.

project_name: Building climate resilient farmlands and restoring the drylands of central Indian tribal belt through Sustainable Agriculture and Natural Resource Management
description:
The stages of implementation has been broken down as per the project activities and deliverables as given below: 
1.	The project seeks to yield both ecological and economic dividends, with a dual focus on enhancing biodiversity and boosting farmers' income by restoring 2,000 hectares.
Key stages of implementation-
Stage 1- Beneficiary selection for practicing NPM and updating baseline and Site profiling- For the main objective of our proposed project is reviving the deteriorating fertility status of the farmlands, it is pertinent to identify farmers and farms that will be focused and acted on. This will enable the mapping and demarcation of 2000 hectares under restoration to track and ensure implementation. This will help to ensure full compliance and outputs and help with the record-keeping. This will probably be done by August 2024.
Stage 2- Capacity building of the farmers to build climate resilient farms- Once the farms are selected, capacity building of the farmers/beneficiaries becomes the next requisite. In order to build climate resilient farms that are more ecologically positive, trainings and technical hand-holding on soil health management practices as well as biological, cultural and nature positive methods of pest, disease and weed management are to be given. The importance of diversification, crop rotation, intercropping and plantations as well as allied activities shall be focused and disseminated.  This will be done throughout the cropping season as and when needed. For the next 6 months, it will be starting by August- September for the upcoming rabi season. 
Stage 3- Soil testing and planning to design Package of Practices for NPM (POP)- As we will be working on soil health, its crucial to measure the OC of the soil samples to take as a baseline and then planning to make a POP particular to crops under NPM covering all protocols like seed germination, seed treatment, seed rate and spacing, use of organic manures and cultures etc. that will ensure to reduce the cost of cultivation and increase the farmer’s income as well as improve the soil health over time. This will be executed in the month of September-October before the onset of the rabi cropping. 
Stage 4- Support for inputs to promote NPM agriculture- Starting from seed availability of different crops to promote seed diversification to ensuring availability of bio-fertilizers and bio-pesticides in subsidized rates from BRCs will help reduce the cost of cultivation for these farmers and thus increase their household income. This will again be done throughout the crop season. The rabi crop usually is sown from November to February/March. 


2.Through ecological diversification, it introduces a variety of crops and farming techniques to bolster ecosystems' resilience to climate fluctuations, thus equipping farmers with more adaptive tools and planting 20,000 trees.
Key stages of implementation-
Stage 1- Trials and Demonstrations-  Through trails of different crops, the suitable varieties and crops are selected and then demonstrated to be adopted by the farmers. We plan on doing the same in the upcoming season including trails of mustard, coriander, lentil and vegetables. All of these being rabi crops will be planted between November-February. 
Stage 2- Provision of seeds- Based on the success of the trials, seeds will be provided to the farmers of different crops promoting diversification and resilience to climate fluctuations. 
Stage 3- Technical hand-holding with the package of practices- To help with the farming techniques, package of practices will be designed and implemented for every crop to ensure better agricultural practices that help equipping farmers for climate resilient farming. This will be done throughout the planting season with the small and marginal farmers identified. 
Stage 4- Land use planning – As an adaptive tool, land use planning is an approach that helps the farmer use his land in an efficient manner to get maximum income out of it. In this approach, fruit trees are planted in a small piece of land to help create an additional source of income for the farmers. This will be done from July-august where tree saplings will be distributed to farmers for planting. 
Stage 5- Site selection for planting trees- For the plantation of trees, site selection will be the first step and identifying whether  it is forest land or revenue land and planning for the plantation accordingly. This should be taken up from July- August 
Stage 6- Identification of ‘van samitis’ and mobilizing them for plantation- On site selection and identification, in forest land plantation can only be done with the ‘van samitis’. So, the next step will be mobilizing and promoting them to plant trees. This should be done by July-August this year. 
Stage 7- Plantation, fencing and watering- Upon mobilizing the ‘van samitis’, digging of the pits will be followed by plantation and thereafter the trees will be fenced and watered through the year by the people of the ‘van samitis’. 


3.It tackles soil erosion and optimizes water retention by employing methods like building check dams and improving drainage lines.
Key stages of implementation-
Stage 1- Site selection- The first step of implementing soil and moisture conservation work is to select the site where it is required 
Stage 2- Designing and planning of the structures- After selection, there will be planning for the structures and designing them to adapt the topography
Stage 3- Technical Sanction and Administrative sanction – This will be followed by the technical sanctioning and administrative sanctioning of the structures
Stage 4- Implementation- Upon this, the structures will thus be built. The time line for the soil and moisture conservation work will be the summer months i.e. April-May 2025. 

4.Innovative water-saving techniques, including mulching and micro-irrigation, are encouraged, alongside the cultivation of crops tailored to local environments, to ensure efficient water use.
Key stages of implementation-
Stage 1- Beneficiary identification- For promoting water-saving techniques, beneficiaries interested to adopt micro-irrigation will have to be identified and then making them understand the need and use of micro-irrigation will be the first step. 
Stage 2- Convergence with govt. schemes and community contribution for ownership- It will be seen if some farmers can be supported both from the project and with convergence from micro-irrigation schemes to subsidize the cost of buying drip and sprinklers. In this step, it will also be seen to set some community contribution to ensure ownership and accountability. 
Stage 3- Implementation- Further, support will be provided to source good quality micro-irrigation systems and to do demonstrations with drip and sprinklers along with practices like mulching to promote adoption of water-saving techniques in farming. 


5.It seeks to foster biodiversity by integrating native species and sustainable farming. Economically, the project aspires to enhance farmer incomes through crop diversification, cost-efficient practices, and added value to their produce.
Key stages of implementation-
Stage 1- Practicing NPM with farmers and plantation- By promoting the adoption of NPM, it will help restore soil health and soil microbial population and foster biodiversity. In addition to this, plantation of indigenous tree saplings will be done in the identified villages so that native species can be promoted. 
Stage 2- Procurement/ Aggregation of pesticide-free and safe produce- To help farmers have access to fair and remunerative prices, support will be given for aggregation to the farmers for transportation and labour costs to help with timely marketing of the pesticide free produce. 
Stage 3- Value addition of the aggregated produce- This aggregated produce will then be processed further to add value and sell to fetch better prices. 
Stage 4- Forward marketing through FPO- The value addition part and the market linkages will be done by the FPO we promote, named RRPPCL. 

6.This comprehensive strategy is designed to empower small and marginal farmers by reinforcing ecosystems to face climate adversities and elevate their economic standing.
Key stages of implementation-
Stage 1- Land use planning- To deal with climate adversities and elevate their income, land use planning is a strategy to be adopted where different fruit trees are given to plant in a said structure which will yield them an additional source of income throughout the year. 
Stage 2- Establishment of kitchen garden- Kitchen gardens or Nutri-gardens will be established with farmers to promote nutritional sufficiency as well as serve as a source for surplus income. Kitchen gardens kits will be distributed in all crop seasons keeping in mind the seasonality of vegetables starting this rabi season i.e. November-December. 
Stage 3- Crop diversification- Crop diversification is the focal point to mitigate the adversities of the climate change and increase the income of the farmers. This will be a focus in every crop season in the upcoming 2 years. 

Note: Community mobilization, Regular capacity building of the farmers and community members  is a common step which will be practiced to ensure proper implementation of the project throughout the project period. Other than that, liaisoning and convergence with various government departments and schemes will also be a common step in all activities to be undertaken under the project, as and when required.

description:
1st intervention Restoration of forest: We will be doing forest restoration across 300 hectares within the Kanha Tiger Reserve's buffer zone, focusing on the eradication of invasive species like Lantana camara and 
promoting natural regeneration of native flora, including grasses, shrubs, and trees by planting 1,00,000 saplings. The selected land will be surveyed for biodiversity. This will be the initial survey for the before elements to be recorded. This will be carried out by first week of August 2024. Flora and fauna will be recorded before the land is prepared for restoration. Later, lantana eradication work will take place, depending on the amount of rainfall we get. There after the sites will be prepared for fencing, pit for poles will be dug. By April to May 2025, pits will be dug for planting saplings. In June 2025, saplings will be obtained, and the plantation process will begin. De-weeding and lantana eradication work will continue every year till the end of the project period. Saplings will be watered in the dry months after monsoon, depending on the moisture level in the soil. Watering of saplings will take place mostly by the end of November 2025 as and when needed. Bio fertilizer will be used in the saplings during the plantation period in June 2025 and during de-weeding in October 2025. 

2nd Intervention Pond rejuvenation: We will be revitalizing 10 natural ponds to foster enduring environmental advantages for local communities and wildlife. This activity will be initiated in April 2025. Ipomoea carnea will be eradicated from the identified village ponds manually. Once the plant is eradicated, it will be kept upside down in a dry area near the site. This will allow the plant to dry up and later can be used by the nearby villagers in the form of fuel wood.

3rd Intervention Micro-plan: Crafting comprehensive micro-plans for 11 villages in the buffer area, promoting 
sustainable development and fostering harmony between humans and wildlife. This activity will initiate from September 2024 and will end by October 2025. We will be making the micro-plan for 11 villages. This will include water source for agricultural land, what kind of NTFP activities take place, etc.

4th Intervention Establishing Self Help Groups: This activity will begin from July 2024. We will arrange a meeting with the villagers in presence of government officials to introduce our objectives and goals of the project. The villagers will be selected for the lantana uprooting work, fencing work & some will be appointed as caretakers for the restoration area. This will create employment opportunity.
We will also create a green nursery for preparing saplings. The saplings created will be utilized in the plantation site. The money will be given to the SHG which will create income for the selected people. The saplings created will be from locally found seeds like Arjuna (Terminalia arjuna), Saja (Terminalia elliptica), Sal (Shorea robusta), Bamboo grass (Bambusa vulgaris) to name a few. The sapling preparation will start from August 2024.

5th Intervention Sensitization: This activity will start from August 2024 and will greatly contribute to community participation and sustainability.

6th Intervention Biodiversity survey: Systematic recording of biodiversity within rehabilitated territories and tracking ecological transformations over time. We will be doing an initial survey before the lantana is removed and one after the lantana is removed. Later, Seasonal data will be collected for all three seasons i.e. monsoon, winter & summer. These surveys will be carried out every year so that we can get a proper data for comparison. This would help in recording the before and after intervention changes.

This involves meetings to determine where public and private tree nurseries will be established within the project areas. Before implementing the program, all parties need to agree on community planting site location, tree-monitoring methodology, and on adherence to a community forestry code. Plant With Purpose DRC then works on capacity building in communities within the project area. Local staff meet with community members and ensure the availability of resources and materials. They collect GPS data for a sample of the sites where tree nurseries will be established, when needed. Environmental technicians on staff provide further training and technical assistance. We then launch tree planting activities and mobilize farmers to plant trees.

Stage 3 MONITORING AND EVALUATION: December 31, 2024 to Approximately August 15, 2029

This stage involves Plant With Purpose DRC staff working with the farmers to monitor and evaluate the planted trees by identifying the growth rate of the trees, the current threats to the trees, keeping track of where the trees are planted (public vs. private land), and seeking solutions to any challenges and threats to the trees in the planting areas. Stage 1: Preparation and Germination of Seeds and Identification of Planting Sites -- This step will take place from January-March of 2024 and 2025 as our hired seedling nursery managers, overseen by Kula Agronomists, will germinate the seeds for coffee trees. Additionally, Kula's Nyamasheke Farm Trainer as well as Kula Operations Director will work with the local government in Nyamasheke to identify sites for planting additional trees. 

Stage 2: Preparation of Seedling Nurseries -- Because Kula has already constructed the seedling nursery in Nyamasheke, this stage will be focused on preparing the nursery bed, making any necessary changes, updates, and expansions to the nursery structure, acquiring quality agroforestry seedlings and transferring the germinated coffee seedlings to the nursery beds. This Stage will be implemented between March-July in 2024 and 2025.

Stage 3: Cultivation of Seedlings -- This stage will encompass the majority of both years from March-October of 2024 and 2025 as seedling nursery managers and Kula Agronomists provide the proper care and inputs needed to grow healthy seedlings as well as hiring local community members to place each seedling in an individual plastic seedling bag.

Stage 4: Identify Additional Farmers and Provision of Training on Proper Planting - Because Kula extends farm support and seedling distribution beyond program participants, we work with the local government to identify additional farmers who are able to receive seedlings based on need and farm expansion capacity. Kula Agronomists then provide planting training and visit each farm in order to ensure proper planting preparation techniques (size of holes dug, distance between holes, etc.). Additionally, through this project, Kula is working with the Nyamasheke District to identify additional land alongside Lake Kivu to plant the remaining indigenous trees in order to further work against land degradation, increase carbon sequestration and reduce the likelihood of erosion for local community members. During this stage, Kula staff, alongside hired community members, will be working to properly prepare these sites for planting. This stage will take place in October 2024 and 2025.

Stage 5: Seedling Distribution and Planting - Due to the rainy seasons in Rwanda, November-December is regarded as planting season. Depending on the amount of rain that is received, planting can take place anytime in November to December and has even extended into January in some recent years. Seedlings are distributed to all Fellows and community members who then plant them in their own individual smallholder farms. Additionally, local community members will also be hired to plant the additional trees in the sites designated by the local government. This will take place between November-December 2024 and 2025.  

Stage 6: Monitoring and Evaluation - Based on the co-designed monitoring plan developed with Terrafund, Kula will implement the agreed upon monitoring and reporting process as well as continue our proprietary Impact Measurement system for the program overall. This stage will take place from 2024-2030.

Throughout each stage listed, Kula will be simultaneously conducting the Kula Fellowship Program, providing monthly agronomy training alongside various farm inputs, business training and investment, and personal development services including mentorship.

project_name: Forest Restoration for Biodiversity and Livelihoods in Asante Akim South Municipal District, Ghana
description: The implementation of the proposed project to restore degraded community forestlands in the Asante Akim South  district will involve several key stages over a period of six years: 1. Community Mobilization and Planning (Year 1): During the first year, the project will focus on community mobilization efforts, conducting meetings, and consultations with local communities. The objective is to raise awareness about the project, gain community support, and establish partnerships with relevant stakeholders. Detailed restoration plans will be developed based on community input and the specific needs and characteristics of the project area. Tree planting activities will also commence in year one, emphasizing the importance of early restoration actions. 2. Site Preparation and Tree Nursery Establishment (Year 1-2): From the first to second year, site preparation activities will take place, including land clearing, soil preparation, and the establishment of tree nurseries. Local community members, including women and youth, will be involved in these activities, providing employment opportunities. The nurseries will serve as a source of seedlings for tree planting in subsequent years. 3. Tree planting and Agroforestry Implementation (Years 1- 2): Years 1 to 2 will focus on the actual tree planting and agroforestry implementation. Tree planting activities will be carried out in cocoa farms and other suitable areas identified through community consultations. Agroforestry systems will be established, combining cocoa cultivation with shade trees and other complementary crops. This approach will enhance biodiversity, improve soil health, provide additional income streams, and promote sustainable land management practices. 4. Maintenance and Monitoring (Years 1-6): Throughout the project, regular maintenance activities will be conducted to ensure the survival and growth of the planted trees. This includes weeding, pruning, and pest control measures. Monitoring and evaluation efforts will assess the progress and impact of the project, tracking parameters such as tree survival rates, biodiversity enhancement, and the socio-economic benefits to local communities. This information will guide adaptive management decisions and ensure the project's effectiveness. 5. Capacity Building and Training (Years 1-6): Capacity building and training programs will be an ongoing component of the project. Training sessions will be conducted for community members, focusing on sustainable land management practices, agroforestry techniques, entrepreneurship skills, and value-addition opportunities. Women and youth will be specifically targeted, empowering them to actively participate in and benefit from the restoration efforts. 6. Project Evaluation and Knowledge Sharing (Year 6): In the final year of the project, a comprehensive evaluation will be conducted to assess the overall outcomes and impact of the project. Lessons learned, best practices, and success stories will be documented and shared with relevant stakeholders, including local communities, government agencies, and other restoration practitioners. This knowledge sharing will contribute to the broader understanding of community-led restoration approaches and help guide future restoration efforts.

description:
1. Mobilisation de toutes les parties prenantes : Pendant cette période, IADL organisera des contacts avec les autres parties prenantes dont : les chefs traditionnels, les leaders locaux et les Organisations Paysannes pour un briefing sur le projet. Cette activité va aller du 29 Janvier au 09 Février 2024.
2. Formation sur la conduite des pépinières ; Une formation de 3 jours en faveur de 6 pépiniéristes (2 pépiniériste par site) et 3 chefs traditionnels sur la conduite d’une pépinière sera organisée.  Le timing imparti pour ce travail va du 1er au 10 mars 2024. 
3. Production des plants: 2 pépinières avec la capacité de produire chacune au moins 25 000 plants par an, seront mis en place dans les sites. Au total chaque pépinière produira au moins 50 000 plants pour le compte du projet. La production des plants va intervenir à partir de Avril 2024 à Septembre 2024 et de Avril à septembre 2025.   
4. Intégration des plants sur les sites :  Les plants seront installés sur les terres déboisés (16,8 ha de boisement pur) et sur les champs de 420 petits producteurs agricoles (agroforesterie) déjà identifié. Les bénéficiaires de ces actions (les petits producteurs agricoles) signeront un protocole d’accord sur la protection des arbres une fois installée. Ces actions vont intervenir du 1er au 30 octobre de chaque année pendant une période de 2 ans de plantation (Octobre 2024 et 2025). 
5. Surveillance des arbres : La surveillance des arbres va se faire par toutes les parties prenantes de ce projet. Les bénéficiaires seront formés sur la gestion des boisements dans un système des essences pure et dans l’agroforesterie.  Ces formations interviendront après la plantation des arbres a chaque mois de novembre pour les années 2024 et 2025.  Les 6 pépiniéristes et 3 chefs locaux seront formés pour suivre l’intégration des arbres dans la communauté. 
6. Le suivi sera assuré par 2 animateurs de IADL et 1 superviseur au moyen des fiches de collecte des données. Cette fiche comportera des éléments suivants : Adresse du site : coordonnées géographique, superficie du site, système appliqué (boisement ou agroforesterie), date de plantation, nombre d’arbre planté par espace, nombre d’arbres détruits par espèces, cause de destruction par arbre, âges de l’arbres détruits et une partie commentaire. 
Les arbres détruits seront regarnies au la campagne suivant des arbres.  Cette collecte des données de sera d’une manière trimestrielle. En mars, Juin, Septembre et Décembre 2024, 2025, 2026, 2027, 2028 et 2029. 
7. Evaluation :  Auto-évaluation : ce projet sera évaluer chaque décembre de l’année par la coordination de IADL en étroite collaboration avec toutes les parties prenantes (les chefs locaux, les membres des organisations paysannes accompagnés et les leaders locaux). 
L’évaluation finale sera faite par le bailleur et collaboration avec toutes les parties prenantes à la fin du projet soit le décembre 2029.

description:
Key Stages for the Implementation of the Project Activities 
•	Baseline Survey and Identification of restoration area.
•	Formation of village level organization and identification of village level volunteer.
•	Capacity building of village level institution, volunteers and communities about the implementation of the project activities
•	Handholding support to communities for implementation of the particular project activities. 
•	Networking with government department.
•	Follow up and monitoring. 

Activity wise implementation stages 
Restoration: - will significantly enhance biodiversity by introducing a diverse array of trees, medicinal plants, and traditional crops, cultivating a rich ecosystem, and promoting local plant varieties. This initiative is expected to strengthen socioeconomic conditions by restoring land and fostering natural farming, thus reducing agricultural costs, increasing soil fertility, and curbing migration by boosting farm yields benefitting over 5,000 individuals. 

•	Baseline Survey and Identification of restoration area: Before implementing the activity we will conduct a baseline survey to find out who is the family with whom we want to do this activity, how much land does the family have, what crops do they grow, whether they have plantation in their fields or not, what kind of farming do they do chemical or organic, how much income they get from farming etc. We will collect all the information so that better planning can be done with the farmers.

•	Formation of village level organization and identification of village level volunteer: The role of village level institutions is more important for better implementation and continuity of the project. After conducting baseline survey and analyzing the problem, we will form village level institutions like SHG/VDC which will help us in better implementation of project activities at the ground level. Along with this, we will identify some volunteers at the village level who will help us in running the project activities smoothly at the village level.

•	Capacity building of village level institution, volunteers and communities: Capacity building is an important part of any program because no program can be successful without capacity building of the functionaries, village level institutions and the community. For example, after formation of any village level organization and identification of volunteers, we will build their capacity on different subjects to make them stronger so that they can reach the right information to the people of the community and make them aware.

•	Handholding support to communities: - After capacity building and training of community and village level institution MJVS team will provide handholding support to community for implementation of activity and taking the benefits of government’s schemes. MJVS has proper monitoring system and monitoring team which checks the success of the activities and gives suggestions.
•	Networking with government department: - Keeping in mind the objectives of the project, it is necessary to contact the Gram Panchayat and government departments so that the distance between the community and the government departments can be mitigate. For that we will organised village level and block level interface meetings between government department and community along with this we will also organised the District and state level consultation meeting with government department for better implementation of government schemes at grass root level.
•	Follow up and monitoring: Follow up and monitoring is a main part of any program because if we are doing any activities with community so their follow-up and proper monitoring is very important. Without follow up and monitoring any program or activities has been not sustained. MJVS has proper team for proper follow up and monitoring of any activities and program. MJVS will undertake follow-up and monitoring at both levels during the project and after the completion of the project.

Watershed development: - watershed infrastructures, such as ponds and dams, in collaboration with local authorities, will elevate water levels, facilitating year-round agriculture and improving community livelihoods. 

•	Formation of village level organization and identification of village level volunteer: The role of village level institutions is more important for better implementation and continuity of the project. After conducting baseline survey and analyzing the problem, we will form village level institutions like SHG/VDC which will help us in better implementation of project activities at the ground level. Along with this, we will identify some volunteers at the village level who will help us in running the project activities smoothly at the village level.

•	Prepare village development plan through the support of village level institution: For works related to soil and water conservation, we will prepare village development plans (micro plans) at the village level with the help of village development committees and village panchayats.

•	Submit village development plan in Gramsabha for the approval through the support of village level institution: After the village development plan is prepared, we will present it to the Gram Sabha for approval with the help of village level institutions (SHGs and VDCs). After the approval of the village development plans, all works related to soil and water conservation will be done by the Gram Panchayat under MGNREGA schemes.

•	Follow up and monitoring during the implementation: After the approval of the village development plans, all works related to soil and water conservation will be done by the Gram Panchayat under MGNREGA schemes. But time to time its monitoring and follow up is more important of better implementation and quality improved. 

Cultivation of Fruit Trees: - The focus on planting predominantly fruit trees serve dual purposes of providing a steady source of income for families and acting as a financial safety net. Food security will see marked improvements through kitchen gardens and the cultivation of fruit trees and indigenous crops, ensuring a reliable source of nutrition for the community. description: We will start the inception phase of the program mid 2022. In the inception phase, together with LEAD Foundation we will start selecting villages and reaching out to village leaders. We will then select champion farmers from these villages, who will be trained at the start of the implementation phase, which starts in October 2022. We will organise Training of Trainers (ToT) sessions, during which our champion farmers receive elaborate training on our regreening techniques, leadership and administrative skills. Once these champions return to their villages and start training other farmers, the actual regreening begins. Gradually, more and more farmers will be activated and start bringing back trees on their farmland. Our rural marketing activities will then start as well, such as the movie roadshow and the SMS service. Champion farmers and program coordinators will play an important role in our monitoring approach in this phase. This phase will continue for three years, during which our champion farmers will receive two more follow-up training sessions. After the implementation phase, the sustainability phase will start in October 2025. Here, we gradually scale down our activities and will have a stronger focus on rural marketing and communication. The aim of the sustainability phase is to at least sustain the realised impact, while we keep promoting the regreening movement. Our champion farmers will play a smaller role and gradually become ambassadors of regreening in their villages. This phase will take another 17 years, which will bring the total program during to 20 years and is proposed to end in October 2042. With this approach, we aim to embed the regreening movement into the communities. For more background about our interventions: https://vimeo.com/325842883

description:
The key stages of the proposed project's implementation are: 
The intended outcomes of the intervention in Sidhi District encompass environmental, social, and economic dimensions, with engaging the primary producers and NTFPs (Non-Timber Forest Products) gathers in value chain and market system to undertake market orientated production and supply of tree- based produces. The expected outcomes and impacts expected over a defined timeline:
•	Environmental: By the end of the project timeline, greater realization of economic and ecological value of important tree species and thereby progress is anticipated in landscape restoration with enhanced biodiversity and improved ecological resilience to climate change impacts. This will be achieved through capacity building of the community on Tree Management Practices, Good Environment Practices, and Sustainable Harvesting Practices.

•	Social: Communities are expected to experience improved livelihoods with positive impact on almost 3000 beneficiaries, creation of 50 jobs, increased income opportunities from sustainable forest-based enterprises. Additionally, social inclusion is aimed for, particularly among marginalized groups, fostering community cohesion and empowerment. The community will be collectivized through 
•	Economic: Over the project duration, there should be visible economic benefits, including higher incomes for farmers and NTFPs gatherers engaged in tree-based value chains, improved market access, and the establishment of sustainable business models. This economic growth is intended to be inclusive, benefiting women and tribal communities.

The following key activities will be undertaken under the aforementioned ESE framework:

1.	Inception Meeting to finalize the Program Design and Action Planning (July/August 2024): ILRT to organize an Inception Meeting, bringing together the HBF and ILRT teams. The meeting will help to bring better understanding about the overall project design and validations of the target set along with discussion of broad approaches, strategies, activities and results.

2.	Stakeholder Consultation at Sidhi for partnerships building with Government and Non-government departments at Sidhi (August/September 2024): The stakeholder consultations will be organized at district level to build a better understanding of the project, its various components and also building partnerships with multiple stakeholders including NABARD, Forest Department, Horticulture Department, SRLMs, KVK, MSME RGMWM and others. This collaborative approach aims to ensure a smoother implementation of the project.

3.	Selection of Geographies, Villages and Target communities around Key Value Chains (July/August 2024): This activity will be done in July/August, 2024, in the designated Majhauli, Sidhi, and Rampur Naikin blocks. The focus will be on identifying villages wherein the Mahua, Jackfruits and Bamboo are already being produced by the farmers as well as there is further potential for plantation of these tree species. This selection process involves a comprehensive assessment of ecological conditions encompassing topography, existing vegetation, current condition of the targeted trees and understanding the impact of climate change on growth patterns and ecological degradation. Integral to this assessment is the active involvement and engagement of local communities within selected villages, their long-term commitment to sustainability and species restoration. Leveraging Geographic Information Systems (GIS) in visualizing ecological parameters, enabling the analysis of spatial data to identify villages conducive to smooth monitoring and evaluation.

4.	Baseline Analysis and Setting Key Performance Parameters (August 2024) This activity will be done in the second quarter, (August 2024), this study will be conducted to comprehensively analyze and grasp the current conditions, challenges, and opportunities within the targeted land areas. This comprehensive assessment will encompass various dimensions, including the identification of the socio-economic condition of the targeted households, livelihood dependency of the households on Jackfruit, Bamboo and Mahua trees, as well as a thorough assessment of potential risks and opportunities associated with the restoration efforts. This baseline study would be used to analyze the impact of this project on the targeted households after the intervention.

5.	Community Mobilization and Organizations (PGs) (Quarter- 1 and Quarter-2 2024): As planned in the project, the community will be collectivized into producer groups so that activities can be undertaken as group activities and meetings, trainings and intervention can be well organized. Thirty contiguous villages will be undertaken where communities are already engaged in Mahua, Jackfruit and bamboo cultivation or collection. 

6.	Capacity Building of Producer Groups (Quarter 2 2024): The community in 30 villages will be collectivized into about 150 Producer Groups. These groups will be farmers with access to either Mahua or Jackfruit or Bamboo or any of the combination. The groups would be trained in governance, record keeping, and saving similar to self-help groups. This group would be basic pillars of the project. ILRT will prepare specific modules in Hindi for training of these groups. The groups may be newly formed or adopted or revived from any existing self-help group in the village.  

7.	Capacity Building for Farmers on Sustainable harvesting and conservation and management practices (Quarter- 3 and Quarter-4 2024/2025 and during fruiting season): The Producer Groups or selected farmers from the group would be provided with training on sustainable harvesting practices, tree management practices for better management and conservation of the trees. ILRT's primary focus lies in capacitating farmers comprehensively, from tree conservation to marketing, and sales of value-added products derived from Mahua, Jackfruit, and Bamboo. The capacity-building programs entail diverse training modules concentrating on planting methodologies, conservation techniques, and agroforestry practices. ILRT is dedicated to educating farmers about the multifaceted economic, environmental, and social benefits derived from conserving and cultivating these three species.

8.	Value Chain Analysis (Quarter - 4 2025 and during fruiting season):  ILRT will conduct a short value chain mapping exercise to map key value chain players (traders, processors, institutions, service providers) to gauge the potential and challenge and also plan point of interventions in value chain development. The community, through Producer Groups, will be trained on the concept of Value Chain and Market System development and specific training will be provided on various dimensions of value chain interventions. 

9.	Value chain Intervention including promoting processing unit (Quarter – 4 2025 and during fruiting season): In relation to Mahua and Jackfruit,  market connect with traders outside Sidhi, value addition interventions including – primary processing of cleaning, and grading would be promoted. Promotion of processing of Mahua and Jackfruit into value-added/baked products will be promoted through establishment of processing unit at cluster level. Similar, opportunity for Bamboo trade, processing and value-addition would be explored and necessary training will be provided to selected producer groups.

10.	Capacity Building for Farmers on Value chain (Quarter - 4 2025 and during flowering/fruiting season): In relation to Mahua and Jackfruit for planned value addition interventions, the producer groups will be provided necessary	trainings with the help of experts and also exposure visit of few selected producer group or farmers would be conducted for their capacity building. 

11.	Documentation of Case stories and Human-Interest Stories: In addition to training, community engagement initiatives to facilitate networking opportunities, the exchange of success stories, experiences, and challenges, would be documented for knowledge sharing and dissmimenation.

12.	Access Finance and Financial Linkages (Quarter - 4 2025 and during Value chain intervention stage) – Access to finance for rural initiatives will be facilitated through partnerships with the State Rural Livelihood Mission, Corporate Social Responsibility, Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs), and others. These collaborative efforts aim to provide essential financial support, resources, and expertise to the targeted households. 

13.	Convergence with Government and other partners (All quarters): ILRT would work to explore opportunities for the communities for plantation, processing or others in relation to value chain promotion of Mahua, Jackfruits, Bamboo or other through Government program, scheme or other opportunities.

14.	Market Planning (during value chain intervention and thereafter)– ILRT aims to strategically position and distinguish its value-added Mahua, Jackfruit, and Bamboo products by concentrating on crafting unique selling propositions (USPs) and defining their value propositions. ILRT would start with trade linkage and market connect for better price for NTFP commodity and then apprach for primary processing with technological interventions.

15.	Monitoring and Evaluation (All Quarters) - ILRT would monitor and evaluate every quarter. For implementing value-added products derived from Jackfruit, Mahua, and Bamboo across the entire production process, from pre-production to post-production stages.

ILRT intend to offer these products across diverse market channels, extending their reach from local markets to the broader Madhya Pradesh (MP) market. This strategic approach seeks to showcase the distinctive benefits and qualities of their products, catering to various market segments while leveraging multiple distribution channels for widespread accessibility and appeal. 4Ps Product, Price, Place, Promotion.

Seed collection and nursery production: October 2023-December 2024. Eden accepts seed on a rolling basis according to our planting goals. It should be noted that in order to prepare for the March 2024 planting season, seedling production must begin in the nursery in October 2023.

Site preparation: March -April 2024 and October - November 2024. Eden's restoration teams prepare planting sites by pitting holes in advance of planting, as well as preparing naturally available bamboo for fencing sections of planted areas where needed.

Planting: During Kenya's rainy seasons which occur March-May and October-December. Over the 1 year planting period, there are 2 planting seasons. Due to uncertainty with rainfall patterns, this gives the organization ample time to accommodate unexpected weather over the planting period to achieve the full planting target.

Fire management trainings and watchtower installation: 2024-2025, dates not yet determined. 

Internal progress review: January 2025. Eden will review planting progress and ensure that operations are on track to hit the goals of the project. project_name: Promoting indigenous trees by restoring Mukungwa river buffer zone in Nyabihu district
description:
The timeline of the project entitled: Promoting indigenous trees by restoring Mukungwa river buffer zone in nyabihu district is as follow: 
Project Launch and Community Awareness (20th January, 2024):
(i)	Conduct a project launch event to engage local communities, stakeholders, and authorities.
(ii)	Initiate awareness campaigns to educate the local community on the importance of restoring the Mukungwa River buffer zone and promoting indigenous trees.
Baseline Assessment, Planning and Stakeholder Engagement (25th January, 2024):
(i)	Conduct a baseline assessment of the current state of the Mukungwa River buffer zone, including soil quality, vegetation cover, and biodiversity.
(ii)	Develop a detailed project plan outlining specific restoration and tree promotion activities.
(iii)	Engage with local communities, government agencies and other stakeholders to gather input and ensure collaboration.
(iv)	Establish partnerships for resource sharing and support.

Local community engagement, capacity building and livelihoods improvement (1st January 2024 to 31st December 2029)
(i)	Conduct training sessions for local communities on sustainable land and water management practices.
(ii)	Build the capacity of community members to actively participate in ongoing restoration of the buffer zone of Mukungwa river.
(iii)	Train local community on the importance of indigenous trees. 
(iv)	Implement income generating activities related to the sustainable use of the restored buffer zone and well management of planted agroforestry trees. 
(v)	Support the development of community led initiatives that align with the goals of the project.

Tree Nursery Establishment (Year 1: 28th January to 30th August, 2024; Year 2: 20th January to 30th August, 2025):
(i)	Set up a tree nursery to propagate indigenous tree species suitable for promoting indigenous trees and restoring the buffer zone of Mukungwa river.
(ii)	Train local community on how to make pots from plantain remnants as means of zero plastic during restoration process. 
(iii)	Train local community members on tree nursery management and tree seedling care.
Tree Planting (Year 1: 1st September-31 December 2024; Year 2: 1st September-31 December 2025):
(i)	Organize community-based tree planting campaigns to plant indigenous trees in the designated buffer zone of Mukungwa river and distribute agroforestry trees to local farmers to be planted in their own farm to control erosion and improve crop harvest. 
(ii)	Regular monitoring and evaluation of planting activities to ensure the successful establishment of indigenous and agroforestry trees.

Monitoring, reporting and verification (Every six months; 6 years) 
(i)	Collect data on nursery site, seedlings to track the progress of project. 
(ii)	Collect data on tree growth to track the progress of project.
(iii)	Collect data on local community engagement and capacity building to track the progress of project.
(iv)	Adaption based on monitoring results and community feedback.
Knowledge Sharing and Dissemination (September, 2029):
(i)	Conduct a final evaluation of the project's outcomes and impact.
(ii)	Collect a comprehensive project report detailing achievements, challenges, and recommendations for future projects.
(iii)	Share project findings, best practices, and lessons learned with local communities, relevant authorities, and other stakeholders.
(iv)	Facilitate knowledge exchange to promote the replication of successful approaches in similar projects.

description:
From February 1, to June 30, 2024: Organize capacity building training for community representatives in tree nursery development, seedling production, tree​ planting and tree caring. This will be combined by identification of the tree nursery locations.

From March 1 –June 15, 2024:  provide all needed equipment and materials to establish permanent tree nurseries that will keep operating for future reforestation efforts.

From March 1 – October 15, 2024 (phase 1) & January 1, September 30 2025 (phase 2):  provide seeds and produce seedlings to be planted. This stage will be related to the seedlings development with a target to plant the seedlings in Both October 2024 & 2025. FHA agronomist will be collaborating with the Sectors agronomist to assist the community member to germinate seeds and relocate them in the polypots for seedlings development.  This will be combined with the capacity building on tree planting and growing to ensure that the community members choose by themselves where they need to plant trees in their plot.

From September 1- October 15, 2024, sign tree conservation agreement with community representatives to ensure the ownership and sustainability.

From October 15, to March 15, 2025 (phase 1) & October 15, to December 15, 2025 (phase 2): Organize tree planting events through which tree conservation messages will be shared and distribute seedlings to the community members for planting in their plots. Trees will be planted in community land, School compound and mining concession focusing on abandoned pits and soil dumping areas. Nursery will keep operating for the whole life of the project.

From April 2025 to the end of the project will be the time to take care of saplings planted and monitor the growth.

The monitoring will be done every six months, through joint visits with local leaders, to evaluate the growth rates and as the nursery will keep operating every planting season dead trees will be replaced by new seedlings. 1)Première phase (2023 – 2025): Cette phase consistera à  la mobilisation et l'accompagnement des bénéficiaires composés des femmes et jeunes petits producteurs  dans le développement de l'agroforesterie pour restaurer les zones touchées par la déforestation par la plantation des arbres fertilitaires et forestiers sauvages ainsi que des arbres fruitiers qui seront introduits dans les champs agroforestiers des populations locales( L’organisation des séances de sensibilisation des bénéficiaires sur l’importance de la restauration paysage végétal  et des services écosystémiques (stockage de CO2, filtration de l’eau, rétention des sols, bien-être des populations, etc.), l'organisation des formations de pépiniéristes locaux, la création des pépinières d’arbres fertilitaires et forestiers sauvages ainsi que des arbres fruitiers ainsi que par l’organisation des campagnes de reboisement en essences d’arbres fertilitaires et forestiers sauvages ainsi que des arbres fruitiers à Kamanyola et ses environs(Kaboya, Migina, Muroha, Mishimumu, Irohero, Kafunda, Kambara, Ihindiro, Nyarubale, kalunga,Luleka),à  Katogota et Luvungi  dans la plaine de Ruzizi au Sud Kivu.
2) Deuxième phase (2026 - 2029): Cette phase sera marquée par l’organisation des activités d’entretien et de surveillance des arbres plantés, la création et le renforcement des capacités des Comités Locaux de Monitoring Forestier, l'organisation des formations pour les jeunes et les femmes petits producteurs en gestion rationnelle d’arbres fruitiers pour la création des AGR(Activités Génératrices de revenus complémentaires pour les petits producteurs locaux et leurs familles) à Kamanyola et ses environs(Kaboya, Migina, Muroha, Mishimumu, Irohero, Kafunda, Kambara, Ihindiro, Nyarubale, kalunga,Luleka),à  Katogota et Luvungi  dans la plaine de Ruzizi au Sud Kivu..
 3) Troisième phase: Cette phase sera consacrée au mesurage des   réalisations à travers les activités de suivi et évaluation du projet ainsi que sur  la définition des nouvelles orientations liées  à la pérennisation  du projet.  Les résultats escomptés de ce projet seront pérennisés  par le maintien des activités du projet par les structures locales de mise en œuvre du projet particulièrement les Comités Locaux de lutte contre la Déforestation et les  Comités locaux des Pépiniéristes, les Comités locaux de monitoring forestier,  les AGR de mise en valeur et vente des fruits locaux de bonne qualité à Kamanyola et ses environs(Kaboya, Migina, Muroha, Mishimumu, Irohero, Kafunda, Kambara, Ihindiro, Nyarubale, kalunga,Luleka),à  Katogota et Luvungi  dans la plaine de Ruzizi au Sud Kivu.. L’existence de ces structures techniques locales de mise en œuvre constitue un dispositif solide d’appropriation et de pérennisation des activités du projet et dont le modèle peut être reproduit à l’échelle dans d’autres sites et villages de la plaine de Ruzizi au Sud Kivu.

project_name: Restoration of dalli lands in Raigad District, Maharashtra
description:
Site selection	- Mar 2024 - 1-2 Dalli plots will be selected in Karjat and/or Khalapur Blocks of Raigad District measuring approximately 50 hectares (125 acres) as restoration sites in consultation with local tribal communities.
Appointment of staff	- Jun-Jul 2024	- Staff will be appointed for the project. Some of the staff will be from our existing team.
Capacity building of staff	- Jun - Dec 2024 - Capacity building programmes will be organised for the project team members on issues such as soil & water conservation measures, local biodiversity, participatory research methodologies, seed collection & storage, nursery raising, tree plantation, live fencing, production and use of organic manures/ bio-pesticides, maintenance of plantation, low-cost irrigation methods, etc.
Community mobilisation - Jun - Sep 2024  - We have been involved in community mobilisation work in this area for a long time on issues such as land and forest rights along with land and forest-based livelihoods of local tribal communities (Thakur, Mahadeo Koli and Katkari) for more than 20 years. As a matter of fact, tribal people have been able to gain possession and collective occupation rights over all the proposed restoration sites (Dalli lands) as part of our work on forest land rights.
Community participation - Regular and on-going - Active participation of the community will be a crucial aspect of the tree plantation programme. Efforts will be made to closely involve members of local tribal communities in various aspects related to site preparation, land surveys, choice of species, digging of pits, seed collection, raising saplings, planting, maintenance, protection, monitoring of the plantations, etc. Community members will be a key stakeholder in the efforts to undertake restoration of degraded Dalli lands.
Site preparation	- Jun 2024 onwards - Work will be initiated on surveys of the Dalli plots, marking of boundaries, clearing of the site, digging of shallow trenches around the sites for planting of a thorny fence followed by a live fence, laying down of baselines and grid lines, etc.
Preparation of organic manures - Jun 2024 onwards - Compost Pits will be dug on different parts of the Dalli plot and organic manures such as compost, Farm Yard Manure, vermicompost, Jeevamrut, etc. will be prepared on the restoration site and used as manure for the plants.
Seed collection - Jun 2024 onwards - A phenology calendar will be prepared to determine the flowering, fruiting and seed collection times of different plant species in the region. Seed collection zones will be marked based on availability of seeds of diverse species. Collection of seeds of different plants will be undertaken at different times of the year depending on availability. The collected seeds will be cleaned, dried, labelled and stored in cloth bags.
Nursery raising - Jun-Jul 2024 onwards - A couple of nurseries close to the restoration site will be contracted for raising saplings of different fruit trees, timber trees, uncultivated food plants, medicinal plants and NTFP species. Saplings of many of these species are generally not grown by nurseries in the region. Assigning the task of raising saplings to existing nurseries will be more cost effective than setting up our own nurseries. Seeds of diverse plant species collected from forest areas will be provided to the nurseries for raising saplings. Direct sowing of seeds will also be done for different plants, especially along the live fence and in rocky/ infertile areas of the restoration site.
Digging of pits - Jun-Jul 2024, Mar-May 2025 - Pits will be dug in the months of summer during 2024 and 2025. 
Thorny fence - Jun 2024 onwards - A dry thorny fence consisting mainly of Karvanda, Pirkut, etc. will be erected around the restoration site to protect saplings that will be planted in the month of June 2024.
Planting of live fence around the site - Jun-Jul 2024 and 2025 - Along with the dry fence, a live fence will be planted around the restoration site with thorny and bushy plant species suitable for growing as hedge plants. Seeds or cuttings of species such as Euphorbia trigona (Pirkut), Vitex negundo (Nirgudi), Carissa congesta (Karvanda), Flacourtia indica (Atrun), Adhatoda vasica (Adulsa), Citrus limon (Limbu), Lawsonia inermis (Mehendi), Acacia concinna (Shikekai), Asparagus racemosus (Shatavari), Jatropha curcas (Chandrajyot); etc. will be planted along the boundary of the land at the onset of monsoon to grow a live fence. The live fence will have multiple benefits. It will protect the plants growing on the land from grazing by livestock, prevent soil erosion, act as a windbreak and also resist forest fires to some extent. The 'live fence' plants have medicinal, food or cosmetic value and can be used for self-consumption or sold in the market.
Tree planting - Jun-Jul 2024 and 2025 - 4-5 month old saplings of some of the fast growing species will be planted in the monsoon season of 2024 while saplings of slow growing plants and plants whose seeds are available only after March-April will be maintained in the nurseries till May 2025. One to one & half year good quality saplings of diverse plant species will thus be available for planting only during the 2025 monsoon seasons. Grafts of fruit trees will be procured from the Konkan Krishi Vidyapeeth at Dapoli, Ratnagiri District or the Fruit Research Station at Vengurla, Sindhudurg District during the 2024 and 2025 monsoon seasons. One year old saplings will not be available in the first year since the saplings grown in nursery during the 2024 monsoon season will be barely 3-4 months old. Planting small saplings will result in a very high mortality rate and will defeat the entire purpose of the restoration programme. In the case of fruit trees (like mango, jackfruit, guava, jamun and cashew) plants will also be grown through direct seeding or by planting seedlings followed by in situ grafting with suitable varieties on one year old plants on the restoration sites. This will result in saving of resources while ensuring better survival and growth of grafted plants. Saplings of Mes and Manya bamboos will be procured from local farmers and planted on the site during the 2024 and 2025 monsoon seasons. Seeds of different plant species collected from the forest will also be used for growing plants in rocky and infertile areas of the restoration site.
Arrangements for watering of plants - 2024 to 2025	- Underground water storage tanks and ferrocement tanks of upto 10,000 litres each will be built at various spots on the Dalli land to improve availability of water for watering of plants. The water tanks will be located at higher levels so that water can flow with gravity. A pump-set and pipeline will be used for lifting water from ponds located at lower levels.
Soil & Moisture Conservation - 2024 - 2025 - Soil & Moisture Conservation measures such as mulching and cover crops will be used extensively to conserve moisture.
Clearing fire breaks or fire lines - 2024 and 2025 - Fire lines or fire breaks will be cleared around the restoration sites during the months of November - December each year to prevent the spread of forest fires into the plantation area during the dry period. Once established, the green live fence will also protect the plants from forest fires to some extent.
Maintenance - 2024 and 2025 - Regular maintenance is the key to ensure good survival and growth of plants on the restoration sites. A calendar will be prepared for carrying out regular maintenance activities such as watering, weeding, turning & loosening of soil, mulching, pruning, and manuring of the plants. Efforts will be made to explore use of low-cost drip irrigation system for watering plants. Organic mulch consisting of wood chips, leaves, twigs or grass will be used around the plants instead of plastic mulch. In the case of pest/ disease attacks, bio-pesticides will be prepared and used to protect the plants. Similarly, organic manures such as compost, Farm Yard Manure, vermicompost, Jeevamrut, etc. will be prepared on the restoration sites and used as manure for the plants.
Monitoring - Jun 2024 onwards - Regular monitoring of the plantation will provide inputs for proper maintenance and protection of the plants growing at the restoration sites. Aspects such as height of plants; health of plants; mortality of saplings; symptoms of pest/ disease attacks; presence of rodents; compaction of soil around the plants; absence of organic mulch; lack of moisture in the soil; functioning of the watering system; effectiveness of the live fence and fire line; protection systems; etc. will be closely monitored periodically to identify any problems or issues pertaining to the plantation. Proper monitoring formats will be prepared with advice and training from experts and a dedicated monitoring team will be given the responsibility to regularly monitor the plantations.

project_name: Restoration of Dry Semi-Deciduous Forest within Bono East Region
description: This proposed project will focus planting activities for the first 2-years and continue monitoring the project for the next 3-years to ensure planted trees are well established and free to grow from competing weeds. Our restoration implementation activities are determined and designed through series of education, town hall meetings, focus group discussion and baseline study involving the local people and the traditional authorities. The local people must agree to stop uncontrolled fire, agree to help plant and manage the trees, and agree to share the revenue. The traditional authorities, the custodians of the land must agree to allocate land for planting. Both activities are developed by the local people so that a fair and transparent system set up to share the revenue. Our implementation stages involve community mobilization, registration of the local people, training and recruitment of seasonal and part-time workers from the local community for nursery construction and management. We contract local famers to engage in seed collection. This is followed by site selection, demarcation and preparation. We engage the local people to manually prepare the planting sites. We supported with cutlasses, axes, hoes, protecting gears, transportation, food and water. After land preparation, we conduct pegging and planting of seedlings. We generally use 3m X 3m planting spacing. After planting, we conduct tree survival assessment. During this stage, we replace all the dead trees. Fires and competing weeds are major threats to planted trees. We maintain the planted trees by managing weeds and fires and occasional grazing. We manage weeds by supporting local people to manually clear their planting sites twice in a year. We recruit, train and contract local people to form community fire management advisory group. This group control, prevent, monitor and suppress fire activities during the dry season when wildfires are very active. We established fire-belts along the plantation boundary. We become part of the community and make our presence well established through project implementation. Our field officers live in the communities and provide day-to-day management and monitoring of implementation activities. The project monitoring team routinely conduct field monitoring once every month. Every six month, the project manager engages with the field officers to discuss the monitoring report and provide solutions to any implementation challenges
