project_name: Rwanda 2023: Promoting Land Restoration through Agroforestry in Rubavu District
description:
Stage 1: Inception phase (February - March 2024)
This stage will involve the following activities:
1. Hiring project team. ARDE has a standardized hiring process that will be used to find a competent team that will help the project achieve its goals. Recruitment of the project team will be conducted as soon as the funding is approved. 
2.	Meetings with key stakeholders for the project launch.
3.	Development of a monitoring framework, getting the inputs of all stakeholders including the farmer's representatives.
4.	The baseline situation analysis will be part of this stages 

Stage 2: Community mobilization (Feb - May 2024)
This stage will involve all activities related to community engagement and capacity building of farmers 
1.	Introduction meetings and confirmation of needs at the community level.
2.	Training of farmers about  sustainable agricultural and land management (SALM), with an emphasis on agroforestry practices (agroforestry products and services, agroforestry farm plan, nursery development, and trees management practices and other SALM practices)
First, consultative meetings with local authorities at district, sector, cell, and village levels will be held. We will meet village leaders, executives of sectors, and district officers (e.g., land managers, environmental officers, etc.) to inform them about the project, how it will be implemented, and the benefits (medium and long-term) that will accrue from the project. Based on our past experience, the meetings with local authorities provide a solid foundation for project implementation and help in community mobilization. The meetings will also help us to confirm the needs, including specific locations affected by degradation such as gullies.
Then, we will convene community meetings with the communities in respective sectors, where the project team members will provide detailed information about the project, including its goals and outcomes, benefits that will, as well as the role of community participation in achieving the project goals. The overall aim of these meetings will be to raise awareness and sensitize farmers about the benefits of adopting agroforestry practices on their farms. 
After awareness-raising meetings, we will form groups of farmers and establish the groups to put in place group leaders who will help to organize the groups. The groups will get agroforestry-related training, the project will train the groups on other aspects to increase their entrepreneurship and business skills, which will further empower the groups and help them improve their livelihoods even after the project ends. 
The meetings will also provide an opportunity to brief the community about the project implementation plan, how the community members will be involved, and the benefits (both direct and indirect) of their involvement. Suggestions and remarks from meetings will be considered during the project implementation. 

Stage 3: Nursery establishment and seedbed preparation (Feb 2024 – Dec  2025 )
We have already identified landowners within the project areas who have agreed to rent us land that will be used to grow seedlings. This stage will include all activities related to nursery development such as nursery construction,  seed sourcing, seedbed preparation, sowing, potting, pricking out, watering, weeding, root pruning, etc. 
We plan to have three nurseries in three sites (sectors) and we will use the land for which we have agreements with landowners (see documentation explaining the project area's land tenure system, File name: Landowners commitments + copies of land documents). Half of the number of seedlings required to plant the target number of trees will be grown in 2024 and another half in 2025.  Nursery managers and farmer groups will get technical training related to nursery establishment and management practices. 
As mentioned in other sections of the proposal, community members will be trained and offered jobs to carry out these activities. We will also train the groups on how to make compost which will be used during the tree planting stage.

Stage 4: Site preparation (Aug  2024 and Aug 2025)
This stage will involve primarily digging holes and adding fertilizer to the holes.

Stage 5: Tree planting (September 2024 -  Dec 2025). 
This stage will involve all activities related to planting (seedling distribution to the farmers, planting of trees in farmland, and practical training related to agroforestry practices. Considering the rainfall pattern, the tree planting stage is planned between September and October, which corresponds to the short rainy season in Rwanda. 

Stage 6: Tree maintenance (From October 2024 to the end of the project)
This will involve all activities related to tree care and tree management. These are continuous activities until the harvest of tree products or the tree itself. This stage will also involve the replacement of dead trees 
This stage will involve activities such as weeding to prevent competition for water and nutrients. Trees may need regular pruning. Farmers will be trained in sustainable harvesting of a multitude of primary and secondary tree products while ensuring proper care for the trees to sustain long-term productivity.

Stage 7: Monitoring and Evaluation (Jan 2024 to the end of the project)
This stage will involve all activities related to monitoring, evaluation, and reporting.  The M&E team will work closely with the project manager to gather data and relevant information on the progress of the project, which will help us in timely reporting. The team will also help in identifying any issues arising during the project implementation. These issues and actions taken to resolve them will be communicated in a timely manner and discussed with WRI. The M&E team will be also supported by an external contractor, who will be hired to support us with some aspects required in reporting such as Field Monitoring and Remote Sensing. The contractor will advise us on how to draw geospatial polygons, how to use satellite data, etc.

project_name: Rwanda 2023: Resilient Community through Forest Landscape Restoration project (RCFLR) in Rutsiro district
description:
Tree planting will be executed only in the first two years to keep four years of maintenance, to make sure that the project will be closed while planted trees are grown enough. The project's main activities include seedlings production, tree planting , community involvement, and maintenance which are expected to be carried out from January 2024 to December 2025
Seedling Production:
Since January 2024, the seedlings production phase has involved a series of critical activities. This includes the identification and construction of the nursery, sourcing/ requisitioning of seeds and planting materials, seed  sowing, evaluation of seed germination, grafting of some fruits trees and the routine nursery maintenance activities. This phase serves as the foundation for the subsequent planting activities, ensuring the availability of healthy and robust seedlings.
Planting Activities:
The timeline from January to December 2025 is allocated for various preparatory tasks, including site identification, site validation, and mapping the site. Community mobilization efforts will run simultaneously, fostering local engagement and support.
Further activities during this period encompass the pegging of planted holes, seedlings transportation, and planting. We will also assess the Species preference  and site selection and other activities including, weeding, beating up, and maintenance will also be done. The planting activities are scheduled to commence in April for some species 
Community involvement
The community, particularly those whose land parcels fall into the mapped landscape will be grouped into landscape community and form the assembly of farmers.

 The engagement extends to the active participation of the community in restoration works, emphasizing the collaborative nature of our approach. To guarantee the impact of our efforts, we prioritize training landscape committees and block leaders in restoration techniques. Additionally, the incorporation of project activities into district performance contracts and the signing of Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) with the district will give assurance of sustainability of the project achievement. Apart from the committee's leaders who will be trained to follow the restoration activities, The project will recruit both skilled and non-skilled laborers, permanent and casual following Rwanda Labor law without any form of discrimination to help in project implementation.

Tree and site maintenance.

Tree and site maintenance activities are integrated into the project's timeline for years 2024 to 2029. In the first two years, maintenance is a crucial aspect since the establishment of the nursery, we will maintain different aspects to keep the health of our seedlings, focusing on routine care such as watering, pest control, and inspections. The nursery site will be maintained by using protective materials like shade nets to prevent and defend the nursery from external threats like pests and diseases.
In subsequent years following nursery activities (2024-2029), ongoing maintenance efforts include periodic inspections, additional care, and rehabilitation if needed. In Planting Activities, we will Implement maintenance activities such as weeding, beating up, and regular inspections to secure the long-term success of the planted trees. During planting season which will start in April 2024, the site to be planted will be well identified and polygons will be created to localize the restoration area. Pegging and holes digging will be monitored and Planted trees will be maintained in the field by the local communities together with the trained elected committees to assist them in caring for the trees.
Monitoring and reporting.

Monitoring and reporting are integral to the project's success. In the initial year, January 2024 marks the first baseline assessment and monitoring of the seedling production phase and nursery establishments, site identification and community mobilization. These activities will be reported to TerraFund through its comprehensive biannual Terramatch reports starting in June 2024. In December 2024 another report will be submitted to TerraMach for the progress of plant activities. As an organization, we have a monthly report that tracks the progress of the activities, and this report will help us to make the Terra Match report for six months.

Talmond has already mobilized the farmers in the Eastern, Ahafo and Volta region who will come under this project. Talmond shall therefore conduct the following activities between January 2024 and 2029.

1.	January 2024: Project onboarding and layout of implementation plan.
2.	February -March 2024: Training of project farmers on site selection and land clearing in readiness for planting. In all, we expect to train 492 farmers across 54 communities in the Eastern, Ahafo and Volta regions.
3.	April 2024: Training of farmers on planting and biochar production. Biochar is good for providing the tree seedling with the ground to adapt to the soil. Biochar helps in the survival of seedlings. At Talmond level, we produce biochar from the shells of the tropical almond nuts or husks. Talmond shall train all our farmers to produce their own organic biochar which will be used during planting. This will be in addition to what Talmond shall support the farmers with.
4.	Mid-April-July 2024: Planting of tropical almond seedlings by farmers. This is the time that rainfall is highest so can provide the seedlings enough moisture to survive. Planting will be done annually in one window in the major season occurring between April to July 2024. The project shall support farmers with the planting according to recommended formats.
5.	July – Dec. 2024: Mapping of farms, profiling of the selected farmers and soil testing of farm lands under restoration. The mapping of the farms is to produce the necessary polygon for all farms under the project. The profiling of the farmers is to establish the necessary baseline for the farmers before the project which will serve as a good ground for evaluating the progress of the project in 2029. 
6.	Jan. 2025-Dec. 2025: Quarterly monitoring on survival rates of planted seedlings. This is the stage of monitoring the progress of the restoration project as well as documenting lessons for future programs. The monitoring plan will detail out the designated periods for monitoring.
7.	Jan. 2026 – Dec. 2026: Bi-annual monitoring of survival and growth rates of planted trees across all project regions.
8.	Jan. 2027 – Dec. 2029: Bi-annual monitoring of tree growth rates and forest cover levels of restored lands under project. This also marks the period of harvesting, processing and supply of tropical almonds to Talmond. This stage is an important aspect of the project because it is here that the project can determine the social and financial benefit of the project to the farmers and Talmond. The use of the tropical almond in this restoration is specific so that the fruits can be processed and sold to Talmond. 
9.	Jan. -Dec. 2029: This is the stage when the project shall consciously evaluate the project contribution to forest cover, biodiversity life, air quality, water storage, soil health, farmer and family livelihoods and wellbeing, job creation and general impact of the project.

project_name: Tree Based Landscape Restoration in SWE for Improved Livelihood and Environmental Sustainability - NABU Ethiopia
description:
In this project we will promote a community-based restoration like enriching forests bordering community areas, closing forest gaps, enriching degraded forests and improve existing agroforestry systems. The activities include the following; 

•	Identification of restoration and nursery sites and selection of tree/shrub species  
•	Establishment of tree nursery sites
•	Cultivation of native (and few exotic species like Grevilia robusta) tree seedlings
•	Plantation of tree seedlings on degraded forest lands 
•	Management and recording of tree growth this include beating up 

Based on an approval of the project the first year will be spent on preparatory activities like community consultation, site preparation, seedling raising, capacity building and plantation of some species which have short nursery life.

The second year will be for plantation of more seedlings and followed by management of the earlier year plantation and beating up. In the third through the fifth year will be mainly on planting, growing, tending (including beating up) and support in economic activities from incorporation fruits and spices in the agroforestry systems.  In the fifth year the number of seedlings to be planted and areas managed through assisted natural regenerations will increase progressively based on experiences of earlier undertakings. In the fourth- and fifth-year experience exchange with interested groups will be undertaken. We will assist the formation of local groups which will be involved in strengthening the community capacity in the production and marketing of various natural resources/forest-based products. In general, every year there will be plantation of trees in addition of the management of formerly planted trees and shrubs.  

Those tree species with long gestation period for timber harvesting like Prunus Africana and Cordia Africana will be maintained for further long terms like 20 years or more.

project_name: Trees for Societal and Economic Empowerment in  Nyandarua County in Kenya (T4SEE)
description:
Key stages of the project implementation will involve the following:
Community Mobilization (February 2024) - this will include holding sensitization meetings within the landscape with an aim of identifying farmers to be included in the project implementation. WWF-K having worked in the landscape in the past, has the knowledge on the strategic areas where such meetings will be conducted with maximum effectiveness. 

Site/Beneficiaries Mapping (Feb - March 2024) - this will partly run concurrently with the community mobilization phase of the project. Once farmers are identified during the mobilization meetings, their available farms for tree growing will be mapped (size & Geo-location) and registered for consideration in the project implementation. As a way of increasing community ownership, WWF-Kenya will train and
facilitate young people to assist with mapping of the beneficiaries within their own communities. This has always proved to be very successful in the past WWF-Kenya interventions.

Sites preparation (March/April & Sept/Oct of each planting year i.e. 2024 & 2025) - this will be done in phases depending on the number of seedlings to be planted in each rainy season. Farmers identified for planting in each season will be mobilized to prepare the land one month before planting. Guidance in terms of spacing and species selection will be offered to the farmers during the site preparation phase.

Seedlings procurement (March & August of each planting year i.e. 2024 & 2025) - this will allow for adequate preparation (including hardening off and transportation to site) of the seedlings for planting in each of the seasons. To address both benefits of seedlings
provenance (site suitability) and communities benefiting (increasing ownership), WWF-K will procure seedlings from
existing community tree nurseries. However, all quality checks for the seedlings to be planted will be guaranteed through collaboration with KFS personnel on the ground.

Planting (April/May & Oct/Nov of each planting year) - weather conditions held constant; the target is to plant double as many seedlings during the long rains (April/May) as compared to short rains (Oct/Nov). Seedlings will be supplied to each farmer based on the size of his/her identified and mapped farm as well as agreed restoration approach (woodlot/inter-cropping). To ensure high survival rates,
supervision will be done by the project team (assisted by community facilitators) to ensure that farmers plant the seedlings immediately after moisture build-up after the onset of the rains. To ensure equity, planting will be distributed equitably in all the identified planting jurisdictions within the 4 planting seasons - unless this is dictated otherwise by an externality such as uneven rainfall distribution.

Maintenance (planting to 6th year after planting) - this will be a joint undertaking between the farmer beneficiary and WWF-K. The farmer will agree to abide by all measures agreed during mobilization and identification phase (including weeding and protection) while WWF-K will continue offering the required advisory and capacity building services to the farmer through a designated project officer.

Monitoring (planting to 6th year after planting) - WWF-K monitoring and evaluation team will support this function throughout the project implementation phase. This will involve such sub-activities as survival counts, growth patterns, reporting and sharing of best practices.
